column2: THE STORY OF YOUNG ABRAHAM LINCOLN
column3: THE STORY OF YOUNG ABRAHAM LINCOLN

column2: CHAPTER I
column3: CHAPTER one

column2: ABRAHAM LINCOLN'S FOREFATHERS
column3: ABRAHAM LINCOLN'S FOREFATHERS

column2: Lincoln's grandfather, for whom he was named Abraham, was a distant cousin to Daniel Boone.
column3: Lincoln's grandfather, for whom he was named Abraham, was a distant cousin to Daniel Boone.

column2: The Boones and the Lincolns had intermarried for generations.
column3: The Boones and the Lincolns had intermarried for generations.

column2: The Lincolns were of good old English stock.
column3: The Lincolns were of good old English stock.

column2: When he was President, Abraham Lincoln, who had never given much attention to the family pedigree, said that the history of his family was well described by a single line in Gray's "Elegy":
column3: When he was President, Abraham Lincoln, who had never given much attention to the family pedigree, said that the history of his family was well described by a single line in Gray's "Elegy":

column2: The short and simple annals of the poor.
column3: The short and simple annals of the poor.

column2: Yet Grandfather Abraham was wealthy for his day.
column3: Yet Grandfather Abraham was wealthy for his day.

column2: He accompanied Boone from Virginia to Kentucky and lost his life there.
column3: He accompanied Boone from Virginia to Kentucky and lost his life there.

column2: He had sacrificed part of his property to the pioneer spirit within him, and, with the killing of their father, his family lost the rest.
column3: He had sacrificed part of his property to the pioneer spirit within him, and, with the killing of their father, his family lost the rest.

column2: They were "land poor" in the wilderness of the "Dark-and-Bloody-Ground"--the meaning of the Indian name, "Ken-tuc-kee."
column3: They were "land poor" in the wilderness of the "Dark and Bloody Ground"--the meaning of the Indian name, "Ken t u c kee."

column2: Grandfather Lincoln had built a solid log cabin and cleared a field or two around it, near the Falls of the Ohio, about where Louisville now stands.
column3: Grandfather Lincoln had built a solid log cabin and cleared a field or two around it, near the Falls of the Ohio, about where Louisville now stands.

column2: But, in the Summer of 1784, the tragic day dawned upon the Lincolns which has come to many a pioneer family in Kentucky and elsewhere.
column3: But, in the Summer of seventeen eighty four, the tragic day dawned upon the Lincolns which has come to many a pioneer family in Kentucky and elsewhere.

column2: His son Thomas told this story to his children:
column3: His son Thomas told this story to his children:

column2: HOW INDIANS KILLED "GRANDFATHER LINCOLN"
column3: HOW INDIANS KILLED "GRANDFATHER LINCOLN"

column2: My father--your grandfather, Abraham Lincoln--come over the mountains from Virginia with his cousin, Dan'l Boone.	My father-your grandfather, Abraham Lincoln-come over the mountains from Virginia with his cousin, Dan'l Boone.
column3: false

column2: He was rich for them times, as he had property worth seventeen thousand dollars; but Mr. Boone he told Father he could make a good deal more by trappin' and tradin' with the Injuns for valuable pelts, or fur skins.
column3: He was rich for them times, as he had property worth seventeen thousand dollars; but mr Boone he told Father he could make a good deal more by trappin' and tradin' with the Injuns for valuable pelts, or fur skins.

column2: You know, Dan'l Boone he had lived among the Injuns.	You know, Dan'l Boone he had lived among the Injuns.
column3: true

column2: He was a sure shot with the rifle so's he could beat the redskins at their own game.
column3: He was a sure shot with the rifle so's he could beat the redskins at their own game.

column2: They took him a prisoner oncet, and instead of killin' him, they was about ready to make him chief--he pretended all the while as how he'd like that--when he got away from 'em.
column3: They took him a prisoner oncet, and instead of killin' him, they was about ready to make him chief-he pretended all the while as how he'd like that-when he got away from 'em.

column2: He was such a good fellow that them Injuns admired his shrewdness, and they let him do about what he pleased.
column3: He was such a good fellow that them Injuns admired his shrewdness, and they let him do about what he pleased.

column2: So he thought they'd let Father alone.
column3: So he thought they'd let Father alone.

column2: Well, your grandfather was a Quaker, you see, and believed in treatin' them red devils well--like William Penn done, you know.	Well, your grandfather was a Quaker, you see, and believed in treatin' them red devils well-like William Penn done, you know.
column3: true

column2: He was a man for peace and quiet, and everything was goin' smooth with the tribes of what we called the Beargrass Country, till one day, when he and my brothers, Mordecai--'Mord' was a big fellow for his age--and Josiah, a few years younger--was out in the clearin' with the oxen, haulin' logs down to the crick.
column3: He was a man for peace and quiet, and everything was goin' smooth with the tribes of what we called the Beargrass Country, till one day, when he and my brothers, Mordecai-'Mord' was a big fellow for his age-and Josiah, a few years younger-was out in the clearin' with the oxen, haulin' logs down to the crick.

column2: I went along too, but I didn't help much--for I was only six.
column3: I went along too, but I didn't help much-for I was only six.

column2: Young as I was, I remember what happened that day like it was only yesterday.	Young as I was, I remember what happened that day like it was only yesterday.
column3: true

column2: It come like a bolt out of the blue.
column3: It come like a bolt out of the blue.

column2: We see Father drop like he was shot--for he _was_ shot!
column3: We see Father drop like he was shot-for he underscore was underscore shot!

column2: Then I heard the crack of a rifle and I saw a puff of smoke floatin' out o' the bushes.
column3: Then I heard the crack of a rifle and I saw a puff of smoke floatin' out o' the bushes.

column2: Injuns! gasps Mord, and starts on the run for the house--to get his gun.
column3: Injuns! gasps Mord, and starts on the run for the house-to get his gun.

column2: Josiah, he starts right off in the opposite direction to the Beargrass fort--we called it a fort, but it was nothin' but a stockade. The way we boys scattered was like a brood o' young turkeys, or pa'tridges, strikin' for cover when the old one is shot.
column3: Josiah, he starts right off in the opposite direction to the Beargrass fort-we called it a fort, but it was nothin' but a stockade. The way we boys scattered was like a brood o' young turkeys, or pa'tridges, strikin' for cover when the old one is shot.

column2: I knowed I'd ought to run too, but I didn't want to leave my father layin' there on the ground.
column3: I knowed I'd ought to run too, but I didn't want to leave my father layin' there on the ground.

column2: Seemed like I'd ought to woke him up so he could run too. Yet I didn't feel like touchin' him.
column3: Seemed like I'd ought to woke him up so he could run too. Yet I didn't feel like touchin' him.

column2: I think I must 'a' knowed he was dead.
column3: I think I must 'a' knowed he was dead.

column2: While I was standin' still, starin' like the oxen, not knowin' what to do, a big Injun come out o' the brush, with a big knife in his hand.	While I was standin' still, starin' like the oxen, not knowin' what to do, a big Injun come out o' the brush, with a big knife in his hand.
column3: false

column2: I knowed what he was goin' to do--skelp my father!
column3: I knowed what he was goin' to do-skelp my father!

column2: I braced up to 'im to keep 'im away, an' he jist laffed at me.
column3: I braced up to 'im to keep 'im away, an' he jist laffed at me.

column2: I never think what the devil looks like without seein' that red demon with his snaky black eyes, grinnin' at me!
column3: I never think what the devil looks like without seein' that red demon with his snaky black eyes, grinnin' at me!

column2: TOM LINCOLN CHASED BY INDIANS
column3: TOM LINCOLN CHASED BY INDIANS

column2: He picked me up like I was a baby an set me on the sawlog, an' was turnin' back to skelp Father, when--biff!--another gun-crack--and Mr. Big Indian he drops jist like your grandfather did, only he wriggles and squirms around, bitin' the dust--like a big snake for all the world!	He picked me up like I was a baby an set me on the sawlog, an' was turnin' back to skelp Father, when-biff!--another gun crack-and mr Big Indian he drops jist like your grandfather did, only he wriggles and squirms around, bitin' the dust-like a big snake for all the world!
column3: false

column2: I was standin' there, kind o' dazed, watchin' another puff o' white smoke, comin' out between two logs in the side of our house.	I was standin' there, kind o' dazed, watchin' another puff o' white smoke, comin' out between two logs in the side of our house.
column3: true

column2: Then I knowed 'Mord' had shot my Injun.
column3: Then I knowed 'Mord' had shot my Injun.

column2: He had run in, got the gun down off'n the wall, an' peekin' out through a crack, he sees that Injun takin' hold o' me.
column3: He had run in, got the gun down off'n the wall, an' peekin' out through a crack, he sees that Injun takin' hold o' me.

column2: Waitin' till the ol' demon turns away, so's not to hit me, 'Mord' he aims at a silver dangler on Mr. Injun's breast and makes him drop in his tracks like I said.
column3: Waitin' till the ol' demon turns away, so's not to hit me, 'Mord' he aims at a silver dangler on mr Injun's breast and makes him drop in his tracks like I said.

column2: Your Uncle 'Mord' he was a sure shot--like Cousin Dan'l Boone.
column3: Your Uncle 'Mord' he was a sure shot-like Cousin Dan'l Boone.

column2: Then I hears the most blood-curdlin' yells, and a lot o' red devils jump out o' the bushes an' come for me brandishin' their tomahawks an' skelpin' knives.	Then I hears the most blood curdlin' yells, and a lot o' red devils jump out o' the bushes an' come for me brandishin' their tomahawks an' skelpin' knives.
column3: false

column2: It was like hell broke loose.
column3: It was like hell broke loose.

column2: They had been watchin' an', of course, 'twas all right to kill Father, but when 'Mord' killed one o' their bucks, that made a big difference.
column3: They had been watchin' an', of course, 'twas all right to kill Father, but when 'Mord' killed one o' their bucks, that made a big difference.

column2: I had sense enough left to run for the house with them Injuns after me.
column3: I had sense enough left to run for the house with them Injuns after me.

column2: Seemed like I couldn't run half as fast as usual, but I must 'a' made purty good time, from what 'Mord' an' Mother said afterward.
column3: Seemed like I couldn't run half as fast as usual, but I must 'a' made purty good time, from what 'Mord' an' Mother said afterward.

column2: He said one was ahead o' the rest an' had his tomahawk raised to brain me with it when--bing!--an' 'Mord' fetches _him_ down like he did the fellow that was goin' to skelp Father.	He said one was ahead o' the rest an' had his tomahawk raised to brain me with it when-bing!--an' 'Mord' fetches underscore him underscore down like he did the fellow that was goin' to skelp Father.
column3: false

column2: That made the others mad an' they took after me, but 'Mord' he drops the head one jist when he's goin' to hit me.
column3: That made the others mad an' they took after me, but 'Mord' he drops the head one jist when he's goin' to hit me.

column2: But all I knowed at the time was that them red devils was a-chasin' me, and I'd got to 'leg it' for dear life!
column3: But all I knowed at the time was that them red devils was a chasin' me, and I'd got to 'leg it' for dear life!

column2: When I gits near enough to the house, I hears Mother and 'Mord' hollerin' to make me run faster and go to the door, for Mother had it open jist wide enough to reach out an' snatch me in--when the third Injun was stoopin' to grab me, but 'Mord' makes him bite the dust like the others.	When I gits near enough to the house, I hears Mother and 'Mord' hollerin' to make me run faster and go to the door, for Mother had it open jist wide enough to reach out an' snatch me in-when the third Injun was stoopin' to grab me, but 'Mord' makes him bite the dust like the others.
column3: false

column2: My, but wasn't them Injuns mad!	My, but wasn't them Injuns mad!
column3: true

column2: Some of 'em sneaked around behind the house--they had to give 'Mord's' gun a wide berth to git there!--but he could only protect the front--and was a-settin' fire to our cabin to smoke us out or roast us alive, jist when the soldiers come with Josiah from the fort and saved our lives.
column3: Some of 'em sneaked around behind the house-they had to give 'Mord's' gun a wide berth to git there!--but he could only protect the front-and was a settin' fire to our cabin to smoke us out or roast us alive, jist when the soldiers come with Josiah from the fort and saved our lives.

column2: Then the Injuns made 'emselves scurce--but they druv off the oxen and all our other stock.
column3: Then the Injuns made 'emselves scurce-but they d r u v off the oxen and all our other stock.

column2: MORD LINCOLN, INDIAN FIGHTER
column3: MORD LINCOLN, INDIAN FIGHTER

column2: That was the breaking up of our family.	That was the breaking up of our family.
column3: true

column2: None of us boys was old enough to take Father's place, an' Mother she was afraid to live there alone. Accordin' to the laws o' Virginia--Kentucky belonged to Virginia then--the oldest son got all the proputty, so 'Mord' he gets it all.
column3: None of us boys was old enough to take Father's place, an' Mother she was afraid to live there alone. Accordin' to the laws o' Virginia-Kentucky belonged to Virginia then-the oldest son got all the proputty, so 'Mord' he gets it all.

column2: He was welcome to it too, for he was the only one of us that could take care of it.
column3: He was welcome to it too, for he was the only one of us that could take care of it.

column2: 'Mord' he wasn't satisfied with killin' a few Injuns that day to revenge Father's death.
column3: 'Mord' he wasn't satisfied with killin' a few Injuns that day to revenge Father's death.

column2: He made a business of shootin' 'em on sight--a reg'lar Injun stalker!
column3: He made a business of shootin' 'em on sight-a reg'lar Injun stalker!

column2: He couldn't see that he was jist as savage as the worst Injun, to murder 'em without waitin' to see whether Mr. Injun was a friend or a foe.
column3: He couldn't see that he was jist as savage as the worst Injun, to murder 'em without waitin' to see whether mr Injun was a friend or a foe.

column2: Oncet when I told 'im there was good an' bad red men like they wuz good an' bad white men, he said I might jist as well say 'good _devil_' as 'good Injun!' He says 'the only good Injun's the dead Injun!'	Oncet when I told 'im there was good an' bad red men like they w u z good an' bad white men, he said I might jist as well say 'good underscore devil underscore' as 'good Injun!' He says 'the only good Injun's the dead Injun!'
column3: false

column2: Well, the settlers must 'a' 'greed with 'Mord,' for they made him sheriff o' the county--he was sech a good shot, too--an' they 'lected him to the Legislatur' after Kentucky come in as a State.	Well, the settlers must 'a' 'greed with 'Mord,' for they made him sheriff o' the county-he was sech a good shot, too-an' they 'lected him to the Legislatur' after Kentucky come in as a State.
column3: false

column2: He stood high in the county.
column3: He stood high in the county.

column2: Folks didn't mind his shootin' an' Injun or two, more or less, when he got the chancet.
column3: Folks didn't mind his shootin' an' Injun or two, more or less, when he got the chancet.

column2: They all looked on redskins like they was catamounts an' other pesky varmints.
column3: They all looked on redskins like they was catamounts an' other pesky varmints.

column2: Your grandmother Lincoln an' Josiah an' me moved over into Washington County, but she had hard scrabblin' to git a livin'.	Your grandmother Lincoln an' Josiah an' me moved over into Washington County, but she had hard scrabblin' to git a livin'.
column3: false

column2: Josiah he stayed with her, an' between him an' 'Mord,' they helped her along, but I had to git out and scratch for a livin'.
column3: Josiah he stayed with her, an' between him an' 'Mord,' they helped her along, but I had to git out and scratch for a livin'.

column2: From the time I was ten I was hired out to work for my 'keep,' an' anything else I could git.
column3: From the time I was ten I was hired out to work for my 'keep,' an' anything else I could git.

column2: I knocked aroun' the country, doin' this, that an' t'other thing till I picked up carpenterin' o' Joseph Hanks, a cousin o' mine, an' there I met his sister Nancy, an' that's how she come to be your mother--an' 'bout how I come to be your father, too!"
column3: I knocked aroun' the country, doin' this, that an' t'other thing till I picked up carpenterin' o' Joseph Hanks, a cousin o' mine, an' there I met his sister Nancy, an' that's how she come to be your mother-an' 'bout how I come to be your father, too!"

column2: Little is known today of Mordecai Lincoln, and there would be less interest in poor Thomas if he had not become the father of Abraham Lincoln, the sixteenth President of the United States.
column3: Little is known today of Mordecai Lincoln, and there would be less interest in poor Thomas if he had not become the father of Abraham Lincoln, the sixteenth President of the United States.

column2: Mordecai Lincoln was a joker and humorist.
column3: Mordecai Lincoln was a joker and humorist.

column2: One who knew him well said of him:
column3: One who knew him well said of him:

column2: He was a man of great drollery, and it would almost make you laugh to look at him.	He was a man of great drollery, and it would almost make you laugh to look at him.
column3: true

column2: I never saw but one other man whose quiet, droll look excited in me the disposition to laugh, and that was 'Artemus Ward.'
column3: I never saw but one other man whose quiet, droll look excited in me the disposition to laugh, and that was 'Artemus Ward.'

column2: Mordecai was quite a story-teller, and in this Abe resembled his 'Uncle Mord,' as we called him.	Mordecai was quite a story teller, and in this Abe resembled his 'Uncle Mord,' as we called him.
column3: true

column2: He was an honest man, as tender-hearted as a woman, and to the last degree charitable and benevolent.
column3: He was an honest man, as tender hearted as a woman, and to the last degree charitable and benevolent.

column2: Abe Lincoln had a very high opinion of his uncle, and on one occasion remarked, 'I have often said that Uncle Mord had run off with all the talents of the family.'
column3: Abe Lincoln had a very high opinion of his uncle, and on one occasion remarked, 'I have often said that Uncle Mord had run off with all the talents of the family.'

column2: In a letter about his family history, just before he was nominated for the presidency, Abraham Lincoln wrote:
column3: In a letter about his family history, just before he was nominated for the presidency, Abraham Lincoln wrote:

column2: My parents were both born in Virginia, of undistinguished families--second families, perhaps I should say.	My parents were both born in Virginia, of undistinguished families-second families, perhaps I should say.
column3: true

column2: My mother was of a family of the name of Hanks.
column3: My mother was of a family of the name of Hanks.

column2: My paternal grandfather, Abraham Lincoln, emigrated from Rockingham County, Virginia, to Kentucky about 1781 or 2, where, a year or two later, he was killed by Indians--not in battle, but by stealth, when he was laboring to open a farm in the forest.
column3: My paternal grandfather, Abraham Lincoln, emigrated from Rockingham county virginia, to Kentucky about seventeen eighty one or two, where, a year or two later, he was killed by Indians-not in battle, but by stealth, when he was laboring to open a farm in the forest.

column2: His ancestors, who were Quakers, went to Virginia from Berks County, Pennsylvania.
column3: His ancestors, who were Quakers, went to Virginia from Berks County, Pennsylvania.

column2: An effort to identify them with the New England family of the same name ended in nothing more definite than a similarity of Christian names in both families, such as Enoch, Levi, Mordecai, Solomon, Abraham, and the like.
column3: An effort to identify them with the New England family of the same name ended in nothing more definite than a similarity of Christian names in both families, such as Enoch, Levi, Mordecai, Solomon, Abraham, and the like.

column2: My father, at the death of his father, was but six years of age; and he grew up, literally without education.
column3: My father, at the death of his father, was but six years of age; and he grew up, literally without education.

column2: CHAPTER II
column3: CHAPTER two

column2: ABRAHAM LINCOLN'S FATHER AND MOTHER
column3: ABRAHAM LINCOLN'S FATHER AND MOTHER

column2: While Thomas Lincoln was living with a farmer and doing odd jobs of carpentering, he met Nancy Hanks, a tall, slender woman, with dark skin, dark brown hair and small, deep-set gray eyes.
column3: While Thomas Lincoln was living with a farmer and doing odd jobs of carpentering, he met Nancy Hanks, a tall, slender woman, with dark skin, dark brown hair and small, deep set gray eyes.

column2: She had a full forehead, a sharp, angular face and a sad expression.
column3: She had a full forehead, a sharp, angular face and a sad expression.

column2: Yet her disposition was generally cheerful.
column3: Yet her disposition was generally cheerful.

column2: For her backwoods advantages she was considered well educated.
column3: For her backwoods advantages she was considered well educated.

column2: She read well and could write, too.
column3: She read well and could write, too.

column2: It is stated that Nancy Hanks taught Thomas Lincoln to write his own name.
column3: It is stated that Nancy Hanks taught Thomas Lincoln to write his own name.
